patternDefinition.title: Require or disallow quotes for attribute values.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-attribute-quotes
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-attribute-quotes

Require or disallow quotes for attribute values.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[target="_blank"] {}
/**     ↑      ↑
 * These quotes */
```

The [`fix` option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/options.md#fix) can automatically fix most of the problems reported by this rule.

## Options

`string`: `"always"|"never"`

### `"always"`

Attribute values _must always_ be quoted.

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title=flower] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[class^=top] {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[target="_blank"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[class|="top"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title~='text'] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[data-attribute='component'] {}
```

### `"never"`

Attribute values _must never_ be quoted.

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[target="_blank"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[class|="top"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title~='text'] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[data-attribute='component'] {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[title=flower] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[class^=top] {}
```

patternDefinition.title: Specify a pattern for class selectors.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-class-pattern
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-class-pattern

Specify a pattern for class selectors.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
    .foo, #bar.baz span, #hoo[disabled] { color: pink; }
/** ↑         ↑
 * These class selectors */
```

This rule ignores non-outputting Less mixin definitions and called Less mixins.

Escaped selectors (e.g. `.u-size-11\/12\@sm`) are parsed as escaped twice (e.g. `.u-size-11\\/12\\@sm`). Your RegExp should account for that.

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`regex|string`

A string will be translated into a RegExp like so `new RegExp(yourString)` — so be sure to escape properly.

The selector value _after `.`_ will be checked. No need to include `.` in your pattern.

Given the string:

```json
"foo-[a-z]+"
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foop {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo-BAR {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div > #zing + .foo-BAR {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo-bar {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div > #zing + .foo-bar {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
#foop {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[foo='bar'] {}
```

## Optional secondary options

### `resolveNestedSelectors: true | false` (default: `false`)

This option will resolve nested selectors with `&` interpolation.

For example, with `true`.

Given the string:

```json
"^[A-Z]+$"
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.A {
  &__B {} /* resolved to ".A__B" */
}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.A {
  &B {} /* resolved to ".AB" */
}
```

patternDefinition.title: Specify a list of allowed combinators.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-combinator-allowed-list
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-combinator-allowed-list

Specify a list of allowed combinators.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
  a + b {}
/** ↑
 * This combinator */
```

This rule normalizes the whitespace descendant combinator to be a single space.

This rule ignores [reference combinators](https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors4/#idref-combinators) e.g. `/for/`.

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`array|string`: `["array", "of", "combinators"]|"combinator"`

Given:

```json
[">", " "]
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a + b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a ~ b {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a > b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a
b {}
```

patternDefinition.title: Specify a list of disallowed combinators.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-combinator-disallowed-list
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-combinator-disallowed-list

Specify a list of disallowed combinators.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
  a + b {}
/** ↑
 * This combinator */
```

This rule normalizes the whitespace descendant combinator to be a single space.

This rule ignores [reference combinators](https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors4/#idref-combinators) e.g. `/for/`.

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`array|string`: `["array", "of", "combinators"]|"combinator"`

Given:

```json
[">", " "]
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a > b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a
b {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a + b {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a ~ b {}
```

patternDefinition.title: Specify a list of disallowed selectors.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-disallowed-list
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-disallowed-list

Specify a list of disallowed selectors.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
    .foo > .bar
/** ↑
 * This is selector */
```

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`array|string|regexp`: `["array", "of", "selectors", /or/, "/regex/"]|"selector"|"/regex/"|/regex/`

If a string is surrounded with `"/"` (e.g. `"/\.foo/"`), it is interpreted as a regular expression.

Given:

```json
["a > .foo", "/\\[data-.+]/"]
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a > .foo {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a[data-auto="1"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo, [data-auto="1"] {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a
>
.foo {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.bar > a > .foo {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.data-auto {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
a[href] {}
```

## Optional secondary options

### `splitList: true | false` (default: `false`)

Split selector lists into individual selectors.

For example, with `true`.

Given:

```json
[".foo", { "splitList": true }]
```

The following pattern is considered a problem:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.bar, .foo {}
```

The following pattern is _not_ considered a problem:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.bar .foo {}
```

### `ignore: ["inside-block"]`

Ignore selectors that are inside a block.

Given:

```json
[".foo", { "ignore": ["inside-block"] }]
```

The following pattern is _not_ considered a problem:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.bar {
  .foo {}
}
```

### `ignore: ["keyframe-selectors"]`

Ignore keyframe selectors.

Given:

```json
["/from/", { "ignore": ["keyframe-selectors"] }]
```

The following pattern is _not_ considered a problem:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
@keyframes fade-in {
  from {}
}
```

patternDefinition.title: Specify a pattern for ID selectors.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-id-pattern
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-id-pattern

Specify a pattern for ID selectors.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo, #bar.baz a, #hoo[disabled] { color: pink; }
/**   ↑           ↑
 * These ID selectors */
```

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`regex|string`

A string will be translated into a RegExp like so `new RegExp(yourString)` — so be sure to escape properly.

The selector value _after `#`_ will be checked. No need to include `#` in your pattern.

Given the string:

```json
"foo-[a-z]+"
```

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
#foop {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
#foo-BAR {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div > .zing + #foo-BAR {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
#foo-bar {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div > .zing + #foo-bar {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foop {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[foo='bar'] {}
```

patternDefinition.title: Limit the number of attribute selectors in a selector.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-max-attribute
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-max-attribute

Limit the number of attribute selectors in a selector.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
    [rel="external"] {}
/** ↑
 * This type of selector */
```

This rule resolves nested selectors before counting the number of attribute selectors. Each selector in a [selector list](https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors4/#selector-list) is evaluated separately.

The `:not()` pseudo-class is also evaluated separately. The rule processes the argument as if it were an independent selector, and the result does not count toward the total for the entire selector.

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`int`: Maximum attribute selectors allowed.

For example, with `2`:

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="number"][name="quality"][data-attribute="value"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="number"][name="quality"][disabled] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="number"][name="quality"] {
  & [data-attribute="value"] {}
}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="number"][name="quality"] {
  & [disabled] {}
}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="number"][name="quality"] {
  & > [data-attribute="value"] {}
}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
/* `[type="text"][data-attribute="value"][disabled]` is inside `:not()`, so it is evaluated separately */
input:not([type="text"][data-attribute="value"][disabled]) {}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="text"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="text"][name="message"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[type="text"][disabled]
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
/* each selector in a selector list is evaluated separately */
[type="text"][name="message"],
[type="number"][name="quality"] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
/* `[disabled]` is inside `:not()`, so it is evaluated separately */
[type="text"][name="message"]:not([disabled]) {}
```

## Optional secondary options

### `ignoreAttributes: ["/regex/", /regex/, "non-regex"]`

Given:

```json
["/^data-my-/", "dir"]
```

For example, with `0`.

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[dir] [data-my-attr] {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
[dir] [data-my-other-attr] {}
```

patternDefinition.title: Limit the number of classes in a selector.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-max-class
patternDefinition.explanation:
# selector-max-class

Limit the number of classes in a selector.

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div .foo.bar[data-val] > a.baz {}
/*  ↑   ↑                 ↑
    ↑   ↑                 ↑
    1   2                 3  -- this selector contains three classes */
```

This rule resolves nested selectors before counting the number of classes in a selector. Each selector in a [selector list](https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors4/#selector-list) is evaluated separately.

The `:not()` pseudo-class is also evaluated separately. The rule processes the argument as if it were an independent selector, and the result does not count toward the total for the entire selector.

The [`message` secondary option](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/tree/16.6.1/docs/user-guide/configure.md#message) can accept the arguments of this rule.

## Options

`int`: Maximum classes allowed.

For example, with `2`:

The following patterns are considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo.bar.baz {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo .bar {
  & > .baz {}
}
```

The following patterns are _not_ considered problems:

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
div {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo .bar {}
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo.bar,
.lorem.ipsum {} /* each selector in a selector list is evaluated separately */
```

<!-- prettier-ignore -->
```css
.foo .bar :not(.lorem.ipsum) {} /* `.lorem.ipsum` is inside `:not()`, so it is evaluated separately */
```

patternDefinition.title: Limit the number of combinators in a selector.
patternDefinition.description: Stylelint_selector-max-combinators

patternDefinition.title: Block Import
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_BlockImportChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Block Import

Block imports, e.g. `import a.{b, c}` can lead to annoying merge errors in large code bases that are maintained by lot of developers. This rule allows to ensure that only single imports are used in order to minimize merge errors in import declarations.

patternDefinition.title: Case Brace
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_CaseBraceChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Case Brace

Braces aren't required in case clauses. They should be omitted according to Scala Style Guide.

patternDefinition.title: Class Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ClassNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Class Names

The Scala style guide recommends that class names conform to certain standards.

patternDefinition.title: Class Type Parameter
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ClassTypeParameterChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Class Type Parameter

Scala generic type names are generally single upper case letters. This check checks for classes and traits. Note that this check only checks the innermost type parameter, to allow for `List[T]`.

patternDefinition.title: Covariant Equals
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_CovariantEqualsChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Covariant Equals

Mistakenly defining a covariant `equals()` method without overriding method `equals(java.lang.Object)` can produce unexpected runtime behaviour.

patternDefinition.title: Curlies Import
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_CurliesImportChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Curlies Import

Curlies imports, e.g. `import a.{b, c}`, can lead to annoying merge errors in large code bases that are maintained by lot of developers. This rule allows to ensure that only single imports, no renaming and no hiding imports are used in order to minimize merge errors in import declarations.

patternDefinition.title: Cyclomatic Complexity
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_CyclomaticComplexityChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Cyclomatic Complexity

If the code is too complex, then this can make code hard to read.

patternDefinition.title: Deprecated Java
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_DeprecatedJavaChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Deprecated Java

You should be using the Scala `@deprecated` instead.

patternDefinition.title: Disallow Space After Token
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_DisallowSpaceAfterTokenChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow Space After Token

Correct formatting can help readability.

patternDefinition.title: Disallow Space Before Token
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_DisallowSpaceBeforeTokenChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow Space Before Token

Correct formatting can help readability.

patternDefinition.title: Empty Class
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_EmptyClassChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Empty Class

If a `class` / `trait` has no members, then braces are unnecessary, and can be removed.

patternDefinition.title: Empty Interpolated String
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_EmptyInterpolatedStringChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Empty Interpolated String

Empty interpolated strings are harder to read and not necessary.

patternDefinition.title: Ensure Single Space After Token
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_EnsureSingleSpaceAfterTokenChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Ensure Single Space After Token

Correct formatting can help readability.

patternDefinition.title: Ensure Single Space Before Token
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_EnsureSingleSpaceBeforeTokenChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Ensure Single Space Before Token

Correct formatting can help readability.

patternDefinition.title: Equals Hash Code
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_EqualsHashCodeChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Equals Hash Code

Defining either equals or hashCode in a class without defining the is a known source of bugs. Usually, when you define one, you should also define the other.

patternDefinition.title: Field Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_FieldNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Field Names

A consistent naming convention for field names can make code easier to read and understand.

patternDefinition.title: File Length
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_FileLengthChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# File Length

Files which are too long can be hard to read and understand.

patternDefinition.title: File Line Length
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_FileLineLengthChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# File Line Length

Lines that are too long can be hard to read and horizontal scrolling is annoying.

patternDefinition.title: File Tab
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_FileTabChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# File Tab

Some say that tabs are evil.

patternDefinition.title: For Brace
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ForBraceChecker

patternDefinition.title: For Loop
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ForLoopChecker

patternDefinition.title: Header Matches
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_HeaderMatchesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Header Matches

A lot of projects require a header with a copyright notice, or they require a license in each file. This does a simple text comparison between the header and the first lines of the file. You can have multiple lines, but make sure you surround the text with a `CDATA` section. You can also specify a regular expression, as long as you set the regex parameter to `true`.

patternDefinition.title: If Brace
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_IfBraceChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# If Brace

Some people find if clauses with braces easier to read.

patternDefinition.title: Illegal Imports
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_IllegalImportsChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Illegal Imports

Use of some classes can be discouraged for a project. For instance, use of `sun._` is generally discouraged because they are internal to the JDK and can be changed.

patternDefinition.title: Import Grouping
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ImportGroupingChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Import Grouping

If imports are spread throughout the file, knowing what is in scope at any one place can be difficult to work out.

patternDefinition.title: Import Order
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ImportOrderChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Import Order

Consistent import ordering improves code readability and reduces unrelated changes in patches.

patternDefinition.title: Indentation
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_IndentationChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Indentation

Code that is not indented consistently can be hard to read.

patternDefinition.title: Lowercase Pattern Match
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_LowercasePatternMatchChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Lowercase Pattern Match

A lower case pattern match clause with no other tokens is the same as `_`; this is not true for patterns which start with an upper case letter. This can cause confusion, and may not be what was intended:

```scala
val foo = "foo"
val Bar = "bar"
"bar" match { case Bar => "we got bar" } // result = "we got bar"
"bar" match { case foo => "we got foo" } // result = "we got foo"
"bar" match { case `foo` => "we got foo" } // result = MatchError
```

This checker raises a warning with the second match. To fix it, use an identifier which starts with an upper case letter (best), use `case _` or, if you wish to refer to the value, add a type `: Any`, e.g.:

```scala
val lc = "lc"
"something" match { case lc: Any => "lc" } // result = "lc"
"something" match { case _ => "lc" } // result = "lc"
```

patternDefinition.title: Magic Number
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_MagicNumberChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Magic Number

Replacing a magic number with a named constant can make code easier to read and understand, and can avoid some subtle bugs.

patternDefinition.title: Method Argument Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_MethodArgumentNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Method Argument Names

The Scala style guide recommends that method argument names conform to certain standards.

patternDefinition.title: Method Length
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_MethodLengthChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Method Length

Long methods can be hard to read and understand.

patternDefinition.title: Method Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_MethodNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Method Names

The Scala style guide recommends that method names conform to certain standards. If the methods are overriding another method, and the overridden method cannot be changed, then use the `ignoreOverride` parameter.

patternDefinition.title: Multiple String Literals
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_MultipleStringLiteralsChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Multiple String Literals

Code duplication makes maintenance more difficult, so it can be better to replace the multiple occurrences with a constant.

patternDefinition.title: Named Argument
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NamedArgumentChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Named Argument

Nameless literals make code harder to understand (consider `updateEntity(1, true)` and `updateEntity(id = 1, enabled = true)`).

patternDefinition.title: New Line At Eof
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NewLineAtEofChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# New Line At Eof

Some version control systems don't cope well with files which don't end with a newline character.

patternDefinition.title: No Clone
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoCloneChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No Clone

The clone method is difficult to get right. You can use the copy constructor of case classes rather than implementing clone. For more information on `clone()`, see Effective Java by Joshua Bloch pages.

patternDefinition.title: No Finalize
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoFinalizeChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No Finalize

`finalize()` is called when the object is garbage collected, and garbage collection is not guaranteed to happen. It is therefore unwise to rely on code in `finalize()` method.

patternDefinition.title: Non ASCIICharacter
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NonASCIICharacterChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Non ASCIICharacter

Scala allows unicode characters as operators and some editors misbehave when they see non-ascii character. In a project collaborated by a community of developers. This check can be helpful in such situations. 

```scala
"value" match {
  case "value" => println("matched")
  ...
}
```

is preferred to

```scala
"value" match {
  case "value" ⇒ println("matched")
  ...
}
```

To fix it, replace the (unicode operator) `⇒` with `=>`.

patternDefinition.title: No New Line At Eof
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoNewLineAtEofChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No New Line At Eof

Because Mirco Dotta wanted it.

patternDefinition.title: Not Implemented Error Usage
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NotImplementedErrorUsage
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Not Implemented Error Usage

The `???` operator denotes that an implementation is missing. This rule helps to avoid potential runtime errors because of not implemented code.

patternDefinition.title: No Whitespace After Left Bracket
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoWhitespaceAfterLeftBracketChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No Whitespace After Left Bracket

If there is whitespace after a left bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.

patternDefinition.title: No Whitespace Before Left Bracket
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoWhitespaceBeforeLeftBracketChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No Whitespace Before Left Bracket

If there is whitespace before a left bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.

patternDefinition.title: No Whitespace Before Right Bracket
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NoWhitespaceBeforeRightBracketChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# No Whitespace Before Right Bracket

If there is whitespace before a right bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.

patternDefinition.title: Null
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NullChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Null

Scala discourages use of `null`, preferring `Option`.

patternDefinition.title: Number Of Methods In Type
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NumberOfMethodsInTypeChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Number Of Methods In Type

If a type declares too many methods, this can be an indication of bad design.

patternDefinition.title: Number Of Types
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_NumberOfTypesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Number Of Types

If there are too many classes/objects defined in a single file, this can cause the code to be difficult to understand.

patternDefinition.title: Object Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ObjectNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Object Names

The Scala style guide recommends that object names conform to certain standards.

patternDefinition.title: Override Java
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_OverrideJavaChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Override Java

You should be using the Scala override keyword instead.

patternDefinition.title: Package Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_PackageNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Package Names

The Scala style guide recommends that package names conform to certain standards.

patternDefinition.title: Package Object Names
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_PackageObjectNamesChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Package Object Names

The Scala style guide recommends that package object names conform to certain standards.

patternDefinition.title: Parameter Number
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ParameterNumberChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Parameter Number

A method which has more than a certain number of parameters can be hard to understand.

patternDefinition.title: Pattern Match Align
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_PatternMatchAlignChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Pattern Match Align

Correct formatting can help readability.

patternDefinition.title: Procedure Declaration
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ProcedureDeclarationChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Procedure Declaration

A procedure style declaration can cause confusion - the developer may have simply forgotten to add a `=`, and now their method returns `Unit` rather than the inferred type:

```scala
def foo() { println("hello"); 5 }
```
This checker raises a warning with the first line. To fix it, use an explicit return type, or add a `=` before the body.

```scala
def foo() = { println("hello"); 5 }
```

patternDefinition.title: Public Methods Have Type
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_PublicMethodsHaveTypeChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Public Methods Have Type

A public method declared on a type is effectively an API declaration. Explicitly declaring a return type means that other code which depends on that type won't break unexpectedly.

patternDefinition.title: Redundant If
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_RedundantIfChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Redundant If

If expressions with boolean constants in both branches can be eliminated without affecting readability. Prefer simply `cond` to `if (cond) true else false` and `!cond` to `if (cond) false else true`.

patternDefinition.title: Regex
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_RegexChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Regex

Some checks can be carried out with a regular expression.

patternDefinition.title: Return
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ReturnChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Return

Use of `return` is not usually necessary in Scala. In fact, use of return can discourage a functional style of programming.

patternDefinition.title: Scala Doc
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ScalaDocChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Scala Doc

Scaladoc is generally considered a good thing. Within reason.

patternDefinition.title: Simplify Boolean Expression
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_SimplifyBooleanExpressionChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Simplify Boolean Expression

A boolean expression which can be simplified can make code easier to read.

patternDefinition.title: Space After Comment Start
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_SpaceAfterCommentStartChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Space After Comment Start

To bring consistency with how comments should be formatted, leave a space right after the beginning of the comment.

```scala
package foobar

object Foobar {
  /**WRONG
    *
    */
  /** Correct
    *
    */
  val d = 2 /*Wrong*/ //Wrong
  /**
    * Correct
    */
  val e = 3 /** Correct*/ // Correct
}
```

patternDefinition.title: Spaces After Plus
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_SpacesAfterPlusChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Spaces After Plus

An expression with spaces around `+` can be easier to read.

patternDefinition.title: Spaces Before Plus
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_SpacesBeforePlusChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Spaces Before Plus

An expression with spaces around `+` can be easier to read.

patternDefinition.title: Structural Type
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_StructuralTypeChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Structural Type

Structural types in Scala can use reflection - this can have unexpected performance consequences. Warning: This check can also wrongly pick up type lamdbas and other such constructs. This checker should be used with care. You always have the alternative of the scalac checking for structural types.

patternDefinition.title: Throw
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_ThrowChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Throw

`throw` statements should be replaced with type-safe error constructs like `Try` and `Either`, which communicate the possibility of error in the type signature.

patternDefinition.title: Todo Comment
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_TodoCommentChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Todo Comment

Some projects may consider `TODO` or `FIXME` comments in a code bad style. They would rather you fix the problem.

patternDefinition.title: Token
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_TokenChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Token

Some checks can be carried by just the presence of a particular token.

patternDefinition.title: Underscore Import
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_UnderscoreImportChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Underscore Import

Importing all classes from a package or static members from a class leads to tight coupling between packages or classes and might lead to problems when a new version of a library introduces name clashes.

patternDefinition.title: Uppercase L
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_UppercaseLChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Uppercase L

A lowercase L (l) can look similar to a number 1 with some fonts.

patternDefinition.title: Var Field
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_VarFieldChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Var Field

`var` (mutable fields) are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.

patternDefinition.title: Var Local
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_VarLocalChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Var Local

`var` (mutable local variables) are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.

patternDefinition.title: While Brace
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_WhileBraceChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# While Brace

While cannot be used in a pure-functional manner, that's why it's recommended to never omit braces according to Scala Style Guide.

patternDefinition.title: While
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_WhileChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# While

`while` loops are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.

patternDefinition.title: Whitespace End Of Line
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_WhitespaceEndOfLineChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Whitespace End Of Line

Whitespace at the end of a line can cause problems when diffing between files or between versions.

patternDefinition.title: Xml Literal
patternDefinition.description: ScalaStyle_XmlLiteralChecker
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Xml Literal

Some projects prefer not to have XML literals. They could use a templating engine instead.

patternDefinition.title: dodgy tool
patternDefinition.description: Dodgy is a very simple tool designed to find ‘dodgy’ things which should not be in a public project, such as secret keys, passwords, AWS tokens or source control diffs.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# dodgy

Dodgy is a very basic tool to run against your codebase to search for "dodgy" looking values. It is a series of simple regular expressions designed to detect things such as accidental SCM diff checkins, or passwords or secret keys hard coded into files.

While this is primarily aimed at open source projects (for whom a publicly available secret key is pretty dangerous), it can also be used in private projects, with the caveat that it will point out things which are not a problem for private projects and is not configurable enough currently to change that.

patternDefinition.title: mccabe tool
patternDefinition.description: McCabe or cyclomatic complexity is a measurement of how many paths there are in a given function or method. It measures how complicated your functions are, and warns if they reach a certain threshold. Methods that are too complex are prone to logic errors, and should be refactored to a series of smaller methods.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# mccabe

McCabe or cyclomatic complexity is a measurement of how many paths there are in a given function or method. It measures how complicated your functions are, and warns if they reach a certain threshold. Methods that are too complex are prone to logic errors, and should be refactored to a series of smaller methods.

patternDefinition.title: profile-validator tool
patternDefinition.description: This is a simple tool built in to prospector which validates prospector profiles.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# profile-validator

This is a simple tool built in to prospector which validates prospector profiles.

patternDefinition.title: pycodestyle tool
patternDefinition.description: pycodestyle is a simple tool to warn about violations of the PEP8 style guide. It produces messages for any divergence from the style guide.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# pycodestyle

Pycodestyle is a tool to check your Python code against some of the style conventions in PEP 8.

patternDefinition.title: pydocstyle tool
patternDefinition.description: Pydocstyle is a simple tool to warn about violations of the PEP257 Docstring Conventions. It produces messages for any divergence from the style guide.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# pydocstyle

Pydocstyle is a static analysis tool for checking compliance with Python docstring conventions.

It supports most of PEP 257 out of the box, but it should not be considered a reference implementation and it supports Python 3.6+

patternDefinition.title: pyflakes tool
patternDefinition.description: Pyflakes analyzes programs and detects various errors. It is simpler and faster than pylint, but also not as thorough.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# pyflakes

A simple program which checks Python source files for errors.

Pyflakes analyzes programs and detects various errors. It works by parsing the source file, not importing it, so it is safe to use on modules with side effects. It’s also much faster.

patternDefinition.title: Checks SQL against the ANSI syntax
patternDefinition.description: Checks SQL against the ANSI syntax
patternDefinition.explanation:
At Codacy we strive to provide great descriptions for our patterns.
With good explanations developers can better understand issues and even learn how to fix them.

For this tool we are not yet meeting this standard but you can help us improve the docs.
To know more, take a look at our [tool documentation guide](https://docs.codacy.com/related-tools/tool-developer-guide/#documentation).

You can also visit the tool's website to find useful tips about the patterns.

patternDefinition.title: Disallows trailing blank lines
patternDefinition.description: Disallows trailing blank lines
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows trailing blank lines at the end of the source file.

YAML configuration example:

```
Layout/TrailingBlankLines:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows trailing whitespace
patternDefinition.description: Disallows trailing whitespace
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows trailing whitespace.

YAML configuration example:

```
Layout/TrailingWhitespace:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows comparison to booleans
patternDefinition.description: Disallows comparison to booleans
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows comparison to booleans.

For example, these are considered invalid:

```
foo == true
bar != false
false === baz
```

This is because these expressions evaluate to `true` or `false`, so you
could get the same result by using either the variable directly,
or negating the variable.

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ComparisonToBoolean:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows calls to debugger
patternDefinition.description: Disallows calls to debugger
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows calls to debugger.

This is because we don't want debugger breakpoints accidentally being
committed into our codebase.

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/DebuggerStatement:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows empty ensure statement
patternDefinition.description: Disallows empty ensure statement
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows empty ensure statement.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def some_method
  do_some_stuff
ensure
end

begin
  do_some_stuff
ensure
end
```

And it should be written as this:

```
def some_method
  do_some_stuff
ensure
  do_something_else
end

begin
  do_some_stuff
ensure
  do_something_else
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/EmptyEnsure
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows empty expressions
patternDefinition.description: Disallows empty expressions
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows empty expressions.

This is considered invalid:

```
foo = ()

if ()
  bar
end
```

And this is valid:

```
foo = (some_expression)

if (some_expression)
  bar
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/EmptyExpression:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows useless conditional statements that contain a literal in place of a variable or predicate function
patternDefinition.description: Disallows useless conditional statements that contain a literal in place of a variable or predicate function
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows useless conditional statements that contain a literal
in place of a variable or predicate function.

This is because a conditional construct with a literal predicate will
always result in the same behaviour at run time, meaning it can be
replaced with either the body of the construct, or deleted entirely.

This is considered invalid:

```
if "something"
  :ok
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/LiteralInCondition:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows useless string interpolations
patternDefinition.description: Disallows useless string interpolations
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows useless string interpolations
that contain a literal value instead of a variable or function.

For example:

```
"Hello, #{:Ary}"
"There are #{4} cats"
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/LiteralInInterpolation
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows rand zero calls
patternDefinition.description: Disallows rand zero calls
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows `rand(0)` and `rand(1)` calls.
Such calls always return `0`.

For example:

```
rand(1)
```

Should be written as:

```
rand
# or
rand(2)
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/RandZero:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows shadowed arguments
patternDefinition.description: Disallows shadowed arguments
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows shadowed arguments.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
do_something do |foo|
  foo = 1 # shadows block argument
  foo
end

def do_something(foo)
  foo = 1 # shadows method argument
  foo
end
```

and it should be written as follows:

```
do_something do |foo|
  foo = foo + 42
  foo
end

def do_something(foo)
  foo = foo + 42
  foo
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ShadowedArgument:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows rescued exception that get shadowed
patternDefinition.description: Disallows rescued exception that get shadowed
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows a rescued exception that get shadowed by a
less specific exception being rescued before a more specific
exception is rescued.

For example, this is invalid:

```
begin
  do_something
rescue Exception
  handle_exception
rescue ArgumentError
  handle_argument_error_exception
end
```

And it has to be written as follows:

```
begin
  do_something
rescue ArgumentError
  handle_argument_error_exception
rescue Exception
  handle_exception
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ShadowedException:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows the usage of the same name as outer local variables for block or proc arguments
patternDefinition.description: Disallows the usage of the same name as outer local variables for block or proc arguments
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows the usage of the same name as outer local variables
for block or proc arguments.

For example, this is considered incorrect:

```
def some_method
  foo = 1

  3.times do |foo| # shadowing outer `foo`
  end
end
```

and should be written as:

```
def some_method
  foo = 1

  3.times do |bar|
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ShadowingOuterLocalVar:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Reports unneeded disable directives in comments
patternDefinition.description: Reports unneeded disable directives in comments
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that reports unneeded disable directives.
For example, this is considered invalid:

```
# ameba:disable Style/PredicateName
def comment?
  do_something
end
```

as the predicate name is correct and the comment directive does not
have any effect, the snippet should be written as the following:

```
def comment?
  do_something
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnneededDisableDirective
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Reports unreachable code
patternDefinition.description: Reports unreachable code
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that reports unreachable code.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def method(a)
  return 42
  a + 1
end
```

```
a = 1
loop do
  break
  a += 1
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
def method(a)
  return 42 if a == 0
  a + 1
end
```

```
a = 1
loop do
  break a > 3
  a += 1
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnreachableCode:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows unused arguments
patternDefinition.description: Disallows unused arguments
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that reports unused arguments.
For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def method(a, b, c)
  a + b
end
```

and should be written as:

```
def method(a, b)
  a + b
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedArgument:
  Enabled: true
  IgnoreDefs: true
  IgnoreBlocks: false
  IgnoreProcs: false
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows useless variable assignments
patternDefinition.description: Disallows useless variable assignments
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows useless assignments.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def method
  var = 1
  do_something
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
def method
  var = 1
  do_something(var)
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UselessAssign:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows useless conditions in when
patternDefinition.description: Disallows useless conditions in when
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows useless conditions in when clause
where it is guaranteed to always return the same result.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
case
when utc?
  io << " UTC"
when local?
  Format.new(" %:z").format(self, io) if local?
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
case
when utc?
  io << " UTC"
when local?
  Format.new(" %:z").format(self, io)
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UselessConditionInWhen:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Enforces constant names to be in screaming case
patternDefinition.description: Enforces constant names to be in screaming case
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that enforces constant names to be in screaming case.

For example, these constant names are considered valid:

```
LUCKY_NUMBERS     = [3, 7, 11]
DOCUMENTATION_URL = "http://crystal-lang.org/docs"
```

And these are invalid names:

```
myBadConstant = 1
Wrong_NAME = 2
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/ConstantNames:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Enforces method names to be in underscored case
patternDefinition.description: Enforces method names to be in underscored case
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that enforces method names to be in underscored case.

For example, these are considered valid:

```
class Person
  def first_name
  end

  def date_of_birth
  end

  def homepage_url
  end
end
```

And these are invalid method names:

```
class Person
  def firstName
  end

  def date_of_Birth
  end

  def homepageURL
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/MethodNames:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows negated conditions in unless
patternDefinition.description: Disallows negated conditions in unless
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows negated conditions in unless.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
unless !s.empty?
  :ok
end
```

And should be rewritten to the following:

```
if s.empty?
  :ok
end
```

It is pretty difficult to wrap your head around a block of code
that is executed if a negated condition is NOT met.

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/NegatedConditionsInUnless:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows tautological predicate names
patternDefinition.description: Disallows tautological predicate names
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows tautological predicate names -
meaning those that start with the prefix `is_`, except for
the ones that are not valid Crystal code (e.g. `is_404?`).

Favour this:

```
def valid?(x)
end
```

Over this:

```
def is_valid?(x)
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/PredicateName:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows redundant begin blocks
patternDefinition.description: Disallows redundant begin blocks
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows redundant begin blocks.

Currently it is able to detect:

1. Exception handler block that can be used as a part of the method.

For example, this:

```
def method
  begin
    read_content
  rescue
    close_file
  end
end
```

should be rewritten as:

```
def method
  read_content
rescue
  close_file
end
```

2. begin..end block as a top level block in a method.

For example this is considered invalid:

```
def method
  begin
    a = 1
    b = 2
  end
end
```

and has to be written as the following:

```
def method
  a = 1
  b = 2
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/RedundantBegin:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Enforces type names in camelcase manner
patternDefinition.description: Enforces type names in camelcase manner
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that enforces type names in camelcase manner.

For example, these are considered valid:

```
class ParseError < Exception
end

module HTTP
  class RequestHandler
  end
end

alias NumericValue = Float32 | Float64 | Int32 | Int64

lib LibYAML
end

struct TagDirective
end

enum Time::DayOfWeek
end
```

And these are invalid type names

```
class My_class
end

module HTT_p
end

alias Numeric_value = Int32

lib Lib_YAML
end

struct Tag_directive
end

enum Time_enum::Day_of_week
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/TypeNames:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows the use of an `else` block with the `unless`
patternDefinition.description: Disallows the use of an `else` block with the `unless`
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows the use of an `else` block with the `unless`.

For example, the rule considers these valid:

```
unless something
  :ok
end

if something
  :one
else
  :two
end
```

But it considers this one invalid as it is an `unless` with an `else`:

```
unless something
  :one
else
  :two
end
```

The solution is to swap the order of the blocks, and change the `unless` to
an `if`, so the previous invalid example would become this:

```
if something
  :two
else
  :one
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/UnlessElse:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Enforces variable names to be in underscored case
patternDefinition.description: Enforces variable names to be in underscored case
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that enforces variable names to be in underscored case.

For example, these variable names are considered valid:

```
var_name = 1
name = 2
_another_good_name = 3
```

And these are invalid variable names:

```
myBadNamedVar = 1
wrong_Name = 2
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/VariableNames:
  Enabled: true
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallows while statements with a true literal as condition
patternDefinition.description: Disallows while statements with a true literal as condition
patternDefinition.explanation:
A rule that disallows the use of `while true` instead of using the idiomatic `loop`

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
while true
  do_something
  break if some_condition
end
```

And should be replaced by the following:

```
loop do
  do_something
  break if some_condition
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/WhileTrue:
  Enabled: true
```

# non-iterator-returned (E0301)

*\_\_iter\_\_ returns non-iterator* Used when an \_\_iter\_\_ method
returns something which is not an iterable (i.e. has no \_\_next\_\_
method)

patternDefinition.title: unexpected-special-method-signature (E0302)
patternDefinition.description: The special method %r expects %s param(s), %d %s given. Emitted when a special method was defined with an invalid number of parameters. If it has too few or too many, it might not work at all.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# unexpected-special-method-signature (E0302)

*The special method %r expects %s param(s), %d %s given* Emitted when a
special method was defined with an invalid number of parameters. If it
has too few or too many, it might not work at all.

patternDefinition.title: used-before-assignment (E0601)
patternDefinition.description: Using variable %r before assignment. Used when a local variable is accessed before it’s assignment.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# used-before-assignment (E0601)

*Using variable %r before assignment* Used when a local variable is
accessed before it’s assignment.

patternDefinition.title: undefined-all-variable (E0603)
patternDefinition.description: Undefined variable name %r in __all__. Used when an undefined variable name is referenced in __all__.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# undefined-all-variable (E0603)

*Undefined variable name %r in \_\_all\_\_* Used when an undefined
variable name is referenced in \_\_all\_\_.

patternDefinition.title: invalid-all-object (E0604)
patternDefinition.description: Invalid object %r in __all__, must contain only strings. Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __all__.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# invalid-all-object (E0604)

*Invalid object %r in \_\_all\_\_, must contain only strings* Used when
an invalid (non-string) object occurs in \_\_all\_\_.

patternDefinition.title: bad-except-order (E0701)
patternDefinition.description: Bad except clauses order (%s). Used when except clauses are not in the correct order (from the more specific to the more generic). If you don’t fix the order, some exceptions may not be caught by the most specific handler.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# bad-except-order (E0701)

*Bad except clauses order (%s)* Used when except clauses are not in the
correct order (from the more specific to the more generic). If you don’t
fix the order, some exceptions may not be caught by the most specific
handler.

patternDefinition.title: raising-bad-type (E0702)
patternDefinition.description: Raising %s while only classes or instances are allowed. Used when something which is neither a class, an instance or a string is raised (i.e. a TypeError will be raised).
patternDefinition.explanation:
# raising-bad-type (E0702)

*Raising %s while only classes or instances are allowed* Used when
something which is neither a class, an instance or a string is raised
(i.e. a TypeError will be raised).

patternDefinition.title: bad-exception-context (E0703)
patternDefinition.description: Exception context set to something which is not an exception, nor None. Used when using the syntax “raise … from …”, where the exception context is not an exception, nor None. This message can’t be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# bad-exception-context (E0703)

*Exception context set to something which is not an exception, nor None*
Used when using the syntax “raise … from …”, where the exception context
is not an exception, nor None. This message can’t be emitted when using
Python \< 3.0.

patternDefinition.title: misplaced-bare-raise (E0704)
patternDefinition.description: The raise statement is not inside an except clause. Used when a bare raise is not used inside an except clause. This generates an error, since there are no active exceptions to be reraised. An exception to this rule is represented by a bare raise inside a finally clause, which might work, as long as an exception is raised inside the try block, but it is nevertheless a code smell that must not be relied upon.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# misplaced-bare-raise (E0704)

*The raise statement is not inside an except clause* Used when a bare
raise is not used inside an except clause. This generates an error,
since there are no active exceptions to be reraised. An exception to
this rule is represented by a bare raise inside a finally clause, which
might work, as long as an exception is raised inside the try block, but
it is nevertheless a code smell that must not be relied upon.

patternDefinition.title: raising-non-exception (E0710)
patternDefinition.description: Raising a new style class which doesn’t inherit from BaseException. Used when a new style class which doesn’t inherit from BaseException is raised.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# raising-non-exception (E0710)

*Raising a new style class which doesn’t inherit from BaseException*
Used when a new style class which doesn’t inherit from BaseException is
raised.

patternDefinition.title: notimplemented-raised (E0711)
patternDefinition.description: NotImplemented raised - should raise NotImplementedError. Used when NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError
patternDefinition.explanation:
# notimplemented-raised (E0711)

*NotImplemented raised - should raise NotImplementedError* Used when
NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError

patternDefinition.title: catching-non-exception (E0712)
patternDefinition.description: Catching an exception which doesn’t inherit from Exception: %s. Used when a class which doesn’t inherit from Exception is used as an exception in an except clause.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# catching-non-exception (E0712)

*Catching an exception which doesn’t inherit from Exception: %s* Used
when a class which doesn’t inherit from Exception is used as an
exception in an except clause.

patternDefinition.title: bad-super-call (E1003)
patternDefinition.description: Bad first argument %r given to super(). Used when another argument than the current class is given as first argument of the super builtin.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# bad-super-call (E1003)

*Bad first argument %r given to super()* Used when another argument than
the current class is given as first argument of the super builtin.

patternDefinition.title: not-callable (E1102)
patternDefinition.description: %s is not callable. Used when an object being called has been inferred to a non callable object
patternDefinition.explanation:
# not-callable (E1102)

*%s is not callable* Used when an object being called has been inferred
to a non callable object

patternDefinition.title: assignment-from-no-return (E1111)
patternDefinition.description: Assigning to function call which doesn’t return. Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function doesn’t return anything.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# assignment-from-no-return (E1111)

*Assigning to function call which doesn’t return* Used when an
assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function doesn’t
return anything.

patternDefinition.title: no-value-for-parameter (E1120)
patternDefinition.description: No value for argument %s in %s call. Used when a function call passes too few arguments.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# no-value-for-parameter (E1120)

*No value for argument %s in %s call* Used when a function call passes
too few arguments.

patternDefinition.title: too-many-function-args (E1121)
patternDefinition.description: Too many positional arguments for %s call. Used when a function call passes too many positional arguments.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# too-many-function-args (E1121)

*Too many positional arguments for %s call* Used when a function call
passes too many positional arguments.

patternDefinition.title: unexpected-keyword-arg (E1123)
patternDefinition.description: Unexpected keyword argument %r in %s call. Used when a function call passes a keyword argument that doesn’t correspond to one of the function’s parameter names.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# unexpected-keyword-arg (E1123)

*Unexpected keyword argument %r in %s call* Used when a function call
passes a keyword argument that doesn’t correspond to one of the
function’s parameter names.

patternDefinition.title: redundant-keyword-arg (E1124)
patternDefinition.description: Argument %r passed by position and keyword in %s call. Used when a function call would result in assigning multiple values to a function parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from a keyword argument.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# redundant-keyword-arg (E1124)

*Argument %r passed by position and keyword in %s call* Used when a
function call would result in assigning multiple values to a function
parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from a keyword
argument.

patternDefinition.title: missing-kwoa (E1125)
patternDefinition.description: Missing mandatory keyword argument %r in %s call. Used when a function call does not pass a mandatory keyword-only argument. This message can’t be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# missing-kwoa (E1125)

*Missing mandatory keyword argument %r in %s call* Used when a function
call does not pass a mandatory keyword-only argument. This message can’t
be emitted when using Python \< 3.0.

patternDefinition.title: invalid-sequence-index (E1126)
patternDefinition.description: Sequence index is not an int, slice, or instance with __index__. Used when a sequence type is indexed with an invalid type. Valid types are ints, slices, and objects with an __index__ method.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# invalid-sequence-index (E1126)

*Sequence index is not an int, slice, or instance with \_\_index\_\_*
Used when a sequence type is indexed with an invalid type. Valid types
are ints, slices, and objects with an \_\_index\_\_ method.

patternDefinition.title: invalid-slice-index (E1127)
patternDefinition.description: Slice index is not an int, None, or instance with __index__. Used when a slice index is not an integer, None, or an object with an __index__ method.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# invalid-slice-index (E1127)

*Slice index is not an int, None, or instance with \_\_index\_\_* Used
when a slice index is not an integer, None, or an object with an
\_\_index\_\_ method.

patternDefinition.title: repeated-keyword (E1132)
patternDefinition.description: Got multiple values for keyword argument %r in function call. Emitted when a function call got multiple values for a keyword.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# repeated-keyword (E1132)

*Got multiple values for keyword argument %r in function call* Emitted
when a function call got multiple values for a keyword.

patternDefinition.title: Expected BEGIN and END statement within conditional logic block
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_conditional-begin-end
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Enforce use of BEGIN and END symbols inside condition statements

## Rule Details

Use BEGIN and END to bind conditional statments as a single block of code.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
  IF (@parm = 1)
    SELECT @output = ‘foo’
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
  IF (@parm = 1)
  BEGIN
    SELECT @output = ‘foo’
  END
```

patternDefinition.title: Cross database inserts or updates enclosed in a transaction can lead to data corruption
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_cross-database-transaction

patternDefinition.title: Expected table to use data compression
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_data-compression
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Requires use of compression option during table creation

## Rule Details

Data compression can reduce database size and can help improve performance of I/O intensive workloads

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
  CREATE TABLE MyTable
    (ID INT,
    Name nvarchar(50))
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
  CREATE TABLE MyTable
    (ID INT,
    Name nvarchar(50))
  WITH (DATA_COMPRESSION = ROW);
```

patternDefinition.title: Data type length not specified
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_data-type-length
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Requires use of length when declaring data types with variable length

## Rule Details

Use of length when specifying data types can help with database size and improve I/O

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
  CREATE TABLE MyTable
    (ID INT,
     Name nvarchar);
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
  CREATE TABLE MyTable
  (ID INT,
  Name nvarchar(50))
```

patternDefinition.title: Found use of CURSOR statement
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_disallow-cursors
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallows use of cursors

## Rule Details

Use of cursors introduces a pattern of row based operations, which less preferred to better performing set based operations

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
DECLARE @id int
DECLARE cursorT CURSOR
FOR
SELECT ProductId
FROM AdventureWorks2012.Production.Product
WHERE DaysToManufacture <= 1

OPEN cursorT
FETCH NEXT FROM cursorT INTO @id
WHILE @@FETCH_STATUS = 0
BEGIN
          SELECT * FROM Production.ProductInventory
          WHERE ProductID=@id
          FETCH NEXT FROM cursorT INTO @id
END
CLOSE cursorT
DEALLOCATE cursorT
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
-- Alternative to cursor statement, using join

SET STATISTICS TIME ON
SELECT * FROM Production.ProductInventory as pinv
INNER JOIN Production.Product as pp
ON pinv.ProductID=pp.ProductID
WHERE pp.DaysToManufacture <= 1
```

patternDefinition.title: Full text predicate found, this can cause performance problems
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_full-text
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallows use of Full Text

## Rule Details

Use of improperly tuned full text queries can lead to performance problems

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT Name, ListPrice
FROM Production.Product
WHERE ListPrice = 80.99
   AND CONTAINS(Name, 'Mountain')
GO
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT Name, ListPrice
FROM Production.Product
WHERE ListPrice = 80.99
   AND Name like '%Mountain%'
GO
```

patternDefinition.title: Expected use of SYS.Partitions rather than INFORMATION_SCHEMA views
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_information-schema
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallows use of INFORMATION_SCHEMA views

## Rule Details

The INFORMATION_SCHEMA are not the best source for object metadata, use SYS.OBJECTS

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT table_name FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES
WHERE table_schema = 'MyTable'
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT name
FROM sys.objects
WHERE OBJECTPROPERTY(object_id, N'SchemaId') = SCHEMA_ID(N'Production')
```

patternDefinition.title: Expected TSQL Keyword to be capitalized
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_keyword-capitalization
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Requires use of capitalized keywords

## Rule Details

Capitalizing SQL keywords enhances readability and provides a clear seperation between keywords and objects

```tsql
select * from foo;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT * FROM foo;
```

patternDefinition.title: Linked server queries can cause table locking and are discouraged
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_linked-server
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallows user of linked server calls

## Rule Details

This rule disallows linked server queries, which can cause table locking and are discouraged

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT Foo
FROM MyServer.MyDatabase.MySchema.MyTable;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT Foo
FROM MyDatabase.MySchema.MyTable;
```

patternDefinition.title: Unaliased table found in multi table joins
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_multi-table-alias
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Enforce aliasing in multi-table joins

## Rule Details

This rule enforces the use of table aliases
when multiple tables are joined in a query.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name, country_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
    INNER JOIN dbo.Country ON id = country_id;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT mt.user_name, c.country_name
FROM dbo.MyTable AS mt
    INNER JOIN dbo.Country AS c ON c.id = mt.country_id;
```

patternDefinition.title: Performing functions on filter clauses or join predicates can cause performance problems
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_non-sargable
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow functions on filter clauses or join predicates

## Rule Details

This rule disallows the use of functions on filter clauses
and join predicates, which can negatively impact performance
by making a query non-SARGable (Search ARGumentable).

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
WHERE DATEDIFF(day, created_on, GETDATE()) <= 3;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
WHERE created_on >= DATEADD(day, -3, GETDATE());
```

patternDefinition.title: Expected use of SYS.COLUMNS rather than ObjectProperty function
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_object-property
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow using ObjectedProperty function over sys view

## Rule Details

This rule disallows using the `ObjectProperty` function
when a sys view could be used instead.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
IF OBJECTPROPERTY(OBJECT_ID(N'dbo.MyTable'),'ISTABLE') = 1
BEGIN
   SELECT 'dbo.MyTable is a table';
END
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
IF EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.tables WHERE name = 'MyTable')
BEGIN
   SELECT 'dbo.MyTable is a table';
END
```

patternDefinition.title: PRINT statement found
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_print-statement
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow using PRINT statements

## Rule Details

This rule disallows using `PRINT` statements.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
PRINT 'This is a debug message.'
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
RAISERROR('This is a debug message.', 160, 1);
```

patternDefinition.title: Object name not schema qualified
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_schema-qualify
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Enforce qualifying objects with schema name

## Rule Details

This rule enforces qualifying references to objects with
schema names.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM MyTable;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable;
```

patternDefinition.title: Expected column names in SELECT
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_select-star
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow selecting all columns with asterisk

## Rule Details

This rule disallows selecting all columns of a table
by using an asterisk.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT *
FROM dbo.MyTable;
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_id, user_name, created_on
FROM dbo.MyTable;
```

patternDefinition.title: Statement not terminated with semicolon
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_semicolon-termination
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Enforce terminating queries with semicolons

## Rule Details

This rule enforces termination of all queries with
a semicolon, as defined by Microsoft's
[Transact-SQL Syntax Conventions](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/language-elements/transact-sql-syntax-conventions-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15)

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable;
```

patternDefinition.title: Expected SET ANSI_NULLS ON near top of file
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_set-ansi

patternDefinition.title: Expected SET NOCOUNT ON near top of file
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_set-nocount

patternDefinition.title: Expected SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON near top of file
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_set-quoted-identifier

patternDefinition.title: Expected SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED near top of file
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_set-transaction-isolation-level

patternDefinition.title: Expected variable to be set using SELECT statement
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_set-variable
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Enforce setting variable with SELECT statement

## Rule Details

This rule enforces setting variable values
using a `SELECT` statement.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
DECLARE @MyVar VARCHAR(30);
SET @MyVar = 'This is incorrect.';
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
DECLARE @MyVar VARCHAR(30);
SELECT @MyVar = 'This is correct.';
```

patternDefinition.title: Use of unicode characters in a non unicode string
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_unicode-string
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow use of unicode chars in non-unicode string

## Rule Details

This rule disallows using unicode characters in
strings that do not support unicode characters.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
DECLARE @MyVar VARCHAR(30) = 'Ⱦhis is incorrect.';
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
DECLARE @MyVar NVARCHAR(30) = N'Ⱦhis is correct.';
```

patternDefinition.title: Use of the UPPER or LOWER functions when performing comparisons in SELECT statements is not required when running database in case insensitive mode
patternDefinition.description: TSQLLint_upper-lower
patternDefinition.explanation:
# Disallow using UPPER/LOWER functions in comparisons

## Rule Details

This rule disallows using `UPPER` or `LOWER` functions
when performing comparisons since this is not required
in case insensitive databases and can affect query SARGability.

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
WHERE UPPER(first_name) = 'NATHAN';
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```tsql
SELECT user_name
FROM dbo.MyTable
WHERE first_name = 'NATHAN';
```

patternDefinition.title: Disallow insecure dependencies
patternDefinition.description: Disallow the use of dependencies with know vulnerabilities
patternDefinition.explanation:
It is common for applications to have dependencies and these dependencies can
have bugs which are hard to detect and can cause security
holes in the application. By checking the Gemfile.lock file, developers are
warned  of gem versions with known security issues in order to avoid bugs more
easily.

patternDefinition.title: Disallow insecure source URIs
patternDefinition.description: Disallow the use of sources with insecure URIs
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checking insecure gem sources is essential once they can be harmful
and susceptible to attacks.


Https should be used:

`source 'https://rubygems.org'`

instead of http:

`source 'http://rubygems.org'`


Https should be used:

`gem 'rails', :git => 'https://github.com/rails/rails.git'`

instead of ssh:
 
 `gem 'rails', :git => 'git@github.com:rails/rails.git'`

patternDefinition.title: Avoid else expressions
patternDefinition.description: Use return statements instead of else expression

parameters.name: exceptions
parameters.description: Comma-separated class name list of exceptions

patternDefinition.title: Avoid static access
patternDefinition.description: Static access leads to hard to test code
patternDefinition.explanation:
Static access increases dependencies and leads to hard to test code. You should instead
 inject dependencies through the constructor

 [Source](http://phpmd.org/rules/cleancode.html#staticaccess)

patternDefinition.title: Detects when a variable is used that has not been defined before
patternDefinition.description: Detects when a variable is used that has not been defined before
patternDefinition.explanation:
Detects when a variable is used that has not been defined before.

[Source](https://phpmd.org/rules/cleancode.html#undefinedvariable)

parameters.name: showClassesComplexity
parameters.description: Indicate if class average violation should be included

parameters.name: showMethodsComplexity
parameters.description: Indicate if method average violation should be included

patternDefinition.title: Cyclomatic complexity
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports methods with high cyclomatic complexity

parameters.name: maximum
parameters.description: The maximum WMC tolerable for a class

patternDefinition.title: Weighted method count
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports classes with a high weighted method count.
patternDefinition.explanation:
The weighted method count metric is defined as the sum of complexities of all methods declared in a class.
This metric is a good indicator how much effort will be necessary to maintain and develop a particular class.
Usually, a WMC higher than 50 is a sign that you need to refactor your code.

[Source](http://phpmd.org/rules/codesize.html#excessiveclasscomplexity)

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: Reporting threshold for the number of lines in a class

patternDefinition.title: Excessive class length
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports excessively long classes.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Long Class files are an indicator that the class may be trying to do too much.
Try to break it down, and reduce the size to something manageable.

[Source](http://phpmd.org/rules/codesize.html#excessiveclasslength)

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: Reporting threshold for the number of lines in a method

patternDefinition.title: Excessive method length
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports excessively long methods.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Long methods are an indicator that the method is doing too much.
Try to break it down, and reduce the size to something manageable.

[Source](http://phpmd.org/rules/codesize.html#excessivemethodlength)

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: Reporting threshold for the number of arguments in a method

patternDefinition.title: Excessive parameters
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports methods with a high number of parameters.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Long parameter lists can indicate that a new object should be created to wrap the numerous parameters.

[Source](http://phpmd.org/rules/codesize.html#excessiveparameterlist)

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: Reporting threshold for the number of public methods and attributes in a class

patternDefinition.title: Excessive public attributes
patternDefinition.description: This pattern reports classes with a high number of public methods and attributes.
patternDefinition.explanation:
A large number of public methods and attributes declared in a class can indicate
the class may need to be broken up. Properly testing a class with a large number of
