patternDefinition.title: Assignment In Operand
patternDefinition.description: Avoid assignments in operands

patternDefinition.title: Unnecessary Block
patternDefinition.description: Unnecessary block.

patternDefinition.title: Equal Comparison
patternDefinition.description: Use '==='/'!==' to compare with true/false or Numbers

patternDefinition.title: Avoid Reassigning Parameters
patternDefinition.description: Avoid reassigning parameters.

patternDefinition.title: Check Result Set
patternDefinition.description: Always check the return of one of the navigation method (next,previous,first,last) of a ResultSet.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when block quotes are indented too much or too little.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when block quotes are indented too much or too little.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when block quotes are indented too much or too little.

  Options: `number` or `'consistent'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used indentation and will warn when
  other block quotes use a different indentation.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when list item checkboxes violate a given style.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when list item checkboxes violate a given style.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when list item checkboxes violate a given style.

  Options: `Object` or `'consistent'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used checked and unchecked checkbox
  styles and warns when subsequent checkboxes use different styles.

  Styles can also be passed in like so:

  ```js
  {checked: 'x', unchecked: ' '}
  ```

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats checked checkboxes using `x` (lowercase X) and unchecked checkboxes
  as `·` (a single space).

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when code blocks do not adhere to a given style.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when code blocks do not adhere to a given style.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when code blocks do not adhere to a given style.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'fenced'`, or `'indented'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used code block style and warns when
  subsequent code blocks uses different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats code blocks using a fence if they have a language flag and
  indentation if not.
  Pass
  [`fences: true`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsfences)
  to always use fences for code blocks.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn for violating emphasis markers.
patternDefinition.description: Warn for violating emphasis markers.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn for violating emphasis markers.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'*'`, or `'_'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used emphasis style and warns when
  subsequent emphasis use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats emphasis using `_` (underscore) by default.
  Pass
  [`emphasis: '*'`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsemphasis)
  to use `*` (asterisk) instead.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn for violating fenced code markers.
patternDefinition.description: Warn for violating fenced code markers.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn for violating fenced code markers.

  Options: `` '`' ``, `'~'`, or `'consistent'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used fenced code marker style and warns
  when subsequent fenced code blocks use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats fences using ``'`'`` (grave accent) by default.
  Pass
  [`fence: '~'`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsfence)
  to use `~` (tilde) instead.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when a line feed at the end of a file is missing.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when a line feed at the end of a file is missing.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when a line feed at the end of a file is missing.
  Empty files are allowed.

  See [StackExchange](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/18743) for why.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  always adds a final line feed to files.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

  ## Example

  ##### `ok.md`

  ###### In

  Note: `␊` represents LF.

  ```markdown
  Alpha␊
  ```

  ###### Out

  No messages.

  ##### `not-ok.md`

  ###### In

  Note: The below file does not have a final newline.

  ```markdown
  Bravo
  ```

  ###### Out

  ```text
  1:1: Missing newline character at end of file
  ```

patternDefinition.title: Warn when too many spaces are used to create a hard break.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when too many spaces are used to create a hard break.
patternDefinition.explanation: Warn when too many spaces are used to create a hard break.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when a heading does not conform to a given style.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when a heading does not conform to a given style.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when a heading does not conform to a given style.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'atx'`, `'atx-closed'`, or `'setext'`,
  default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used heading style and warns when
  subsequent headings use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats headings as ATX by default.
  This can be configured with the
  [`setext`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionssetext)
  and
  [`closeAtx`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionscloseatx)
  options.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when link and definition titles occur with incorrect quotes.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when link and definition titles occur with incorrect quotes.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when link and definition titles occur with incorrect quotes.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'"'`, `'\''`, or `'()'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used quote style and warns when subsequent
  titles use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  uses `'` (single quote) for titles if they contain a double quote, and `"`
  (double quotes) otherwise.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when list item bullets are indented.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when list item bullets are indented.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when list item bullets are indented.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  removes all indentation before bullets.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when the content of a list item has mixed indentation.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when the content of a list item has mixed indentation.
patternDefinition.explanation: Warn when the content of a list item has mixed indentation.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when the spacing between a list item’s bullet and its content violates
patternDefinition.description: Warn when the spacing between a list item’s bullet and its content violates
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when the spacing between a list item’s bullet and its content violates
  a given style.

  Options: `'tab-size'`, `'mixed'`, or `'space'`, default: `'tab-size'`.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  uses `'tab-size'` (named `'tab'` there) by default to ensure Markdown is
  seen the same way across vendors.
  This can be configured with the
  [`listItemIndent`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionslistitemindent)
  option.
  This rule’s `'space'` option is named `'1'` there.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn for autolinks without protocol.
patternDefinition.description: Warn for autolinks without protocol.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn for autolinks without protocol.
  Autolinks are URLs enclosed in `<` (less than) and `>` (greater than)
  characters.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  adds a protocol where needed.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when blank lines without `>` (greater than) markers are found in a
patternDefinition.description: Warn when blank lines without `>` (greater than) markers are found in a
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when blank lines without `>` (greater than) markers are found in a
  block quote.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  adds markers to every line in a block quote.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when duplicate definitions are found.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when duplicate definitions are found.
patternDefinition.explanation: Warn when duplicate definitions are found.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when content of headings is indented.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when content of headings is indented.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when content of headings is indented.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  removes all unneeded padding around content in headings.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when phrasing content is padded with spaces between their markers and
patternDefinition.description: Warn when phrasing content is padded with spaces between their markers and
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when phrasing content is padded with spaces between their markers and
  content.

  Warns for emphasis, strong, delete, image, and link.

patternDefinition.title: Warn for literal URLs in text.
patternDefinition.description: Warn for literal URLs in text.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn for literal URLs in text.
  URLs are treated as links in some Markdown vendors, but not in others.
  To make sure they are always linked, wrap them in `<` (less than) and `>`
  (greater than).

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  never creates literal URLs and always uses `<` (less than) and `>`
  (greater than).

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when shortcut reference images are used.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when shortcut reference images are used.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when shortcut reference images are used.

  Shortcut references render as images when a definition is found, and as
  plain text without definition.
  Sometimes, you don’t intend to create an image from the reference, but this
  rule still warns anyway.
  In that case, you can escape the reference like so: `!\[foo]`.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when shortcut reference links are used.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when shortcut reference links are used.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when shortcut reference links are used.

  Shortcut references render as links when a definition is found, and as
  plain text without definition.
  Sometimes, you don’t intend to create a link from the reference, but this
  rule still warns anyway.
  In that case, you can escape the reference like so: `\[foo]`.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when references to undefined definitions are found.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when references to undefined definitions are found.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when references to undefined definitions are found.

  Options: `Object`, optional.

  The object can have an `allow` field, set to an array of strings that may
  appear between `[` and `]`, but that should not be treated as link
  identifiers.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when unused definitions are found.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when unused definitions are found.
patternDefinition.explanation: Warn when unused definitions are found.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when the list item marker style of ordered lists violate a given style.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when the list item marker style of ordered lists violate a given style.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when the list item marker style of ordered lists violate a given style.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'.'`, or `')'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used list style and warns when subsequent
  lists use different styles.

  Note: `)` is only supported in CommonMark.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when the thematic breaks (horizontal rules) violate a given or
patternDefinition.description: Warn when the thematic breaks (horizontal rules) violate a given or
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when the thematic breaks (horizontal rules) violate a given or
  detected style.

  Options: `string`, either a corect thematic breaks such as `***`, or
  `'consistent'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used thematic break style and warns when
  subsequent rules use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  has three settings that define how rules are created:

  *   [`rule`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsrule)
      (default: `*`) — Marker to use
  *   [`ruleRepetition`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsrulerepetition)
      (default: `3`) — Number of markers to use
  *   [`ruleSpaces`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsrulespaces)
      (default: `true`) — Whether to pad markers with spaces

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn for violating importance (strong) markers.
patternDefinition.description: Warn for violating importance (strong) markers.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn for violating importance (strong) markers.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'*'`, or `'_'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used importance style and warns when
  subsequent importance sequences use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats importance using an `*` (asterisk) by default.
  Pass
  [`strong: '_'`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsstrong)
  to use `_` (underscore) instead.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

patternDefinition.title: Warn when table cells are incorrectly padded.
patternDefinition.description: Warn when table cells are incorrectly padded.
patternDefinition.explanation:
Warn when table cells are incorrectly padded.

  Options: `'consistent'`, `'padded'`, or `'compact'`, default: `'consistent'`.

  `'consistent'` detects the first used cell padding style and warns when
  subsequent cells use different styles.

  ## Fix

  [`remark-stringify`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify)
  formats tables with padding by default.
  Pass
  [`spacedTable: false`](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark/tree/HEAD/packages/remark-stringify#optionsspacedtable)
  to not use padding.

  See [Using remark to fix your Markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint#using-remark-to-fix-your-markdown)
  on how to automatically fix warnings for this rule.

parameters.name: allowClassImports
parameters.description: Control whether to allow starred class imports like import java.util.*;.

parameters.name: allowStaticMemberImports
parameters.description: Control whether to allow starred static member imports like import static org.junit.Assert.*;.

parameters.name: excludes
parameters.description: Specify packages where starred class imports are allowed and classes where starred static member imports are allowed.

patternDefinition.title: AvoidStarImport
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_AvoidStarImport
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks that there are no import statements that use the `*` notation.

Rationale: Importing all classes from a package or static members from a
class leads to tight coupling between packages or classes and might lead
to problems when a new version of a library introduces name clashes.

patternDefinition.title: CommentsIndentation
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_CommentsIndentation
patternDefinition.explanation:
Controls the indentation between comments and surrounding code. Comments
are indented at the same level as the surrounding code. Detailed info
about such convention can be found
[here](../../styleguides/google-java-style-20220203/javaguide.html#s4.8.6.1-block-comment-style)

parameters.name: option
parameters.description: Specify the policy on block contents.

parameters.name: tokens
parameters.default: LITERAL_WHILE, LITERAL_TRY, LITERAL_FINALLY, LITERAL_DO, LITERAL_IF, LITERAL_ELSE, LITERAL_FOR, INSTANCE_INIT, STATIC_INIT, LITERAL_SWITCH, LITERAL_SYNCHRONIZED

patternDefinition.title: EmptyBlock
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_EmptyBlock
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks for empty blocks. This check does not validate sequential blocks.

Sequential blocks won't be checked. Also, no violations for fallthrough:

    switch (a) {
      case 1:                          // no violation
      case 2:                          // no violation
      case 3: someMethod(); { }        // no violation
      default: break;
    }
            

NOTE: This check processes LITERAL_CASE and LITERAL_DEFAULT separately.
Verification empty block is done for single nearest {@code case} or
{@code default}.

parameters.name: tokens
parameters.value: LITERAL_WHILE, LITERAL_TRY, LITERAL_FINALLY, LITERAL_DO, LITERAL_IF, LITERAL_ELSE, LITERAL_FOR, INSTANCE_INIT, STATIC_INIT, LITERAL_SWITCH, LITERAL_SYNCHRONIZED

parameters.name: commentFormat
parameters.description: Specify the RegExp for the first comment inside empty catch block. If check meets comment inside empty catch block matching specified format - empty block is suppressed. If it is multi-line comment - only its first line is analyzed.

parameters.name: exceptionVariableName
parameters.description: Specify the RegExp for the name of the variable associated with exception. If check meets variable name matching specified value - empty block is suppressed.

patternDefinition.title: EmptyCatchBlock
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_EmptyCatchBlock
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks for empty catch blocks. By default, check allows empty catch
block with any comment inside.

parameters.name: allowMultipleEmptyLines
parameters.description: Allow multiple empty lines between class members.

parameters.name: allowMultipleEmptyLinesInsideClassMembers
parameters.description: Allow multiple empty lines inside class members.

parameters.name: allowNoEmptyLineBetweenFields
parameters.description: Allow no empty line between fields.

parameters.name: tokens
parameters.default: PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT, STATIC_IMPORT, CLASS_DEF, INTERFACE_DEF, ENUM_DEF, STATIC_INIT, INSTANCE_INIT, METHOD_DEF, CTOR_DEF, VARIABLE_DEF, RECORD_DEF, COMPACT_CTOR_DEF

patternDefinition.title: EmptyLineSeparator
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_EmptyLineSeparator
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks for empty line separators before package, all import
declarations, fields, constructors, methods, nested classes, static
initializers and instance initializers.

Checks for empty line separators before not only statements but
implementation and documentation comments and blocks as well.

ATTENTION: empty line separator is required between token siblings, not
after line where token is found. If token does not have a sibling of the
same type, then empty line is required at its end (for example for
CLASS_DEF it is after '}'). Also, trailing comments are skipped.

parameters.name: tokens
parameters.value: PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT, STATIC_IMPORT, CLASS_DEF, INTERFACE_DEF, ENUM_DEF, STATIC_INIT, INSTANCE_INIT, METHOD_DEF, CTOR_DEF, VARIABLE_DEF, RECORD_DEF, COMPACT_CTOR_DEF

parameters.name: eachLine
parameters.description: Control whether to report on each line containing a tab, or just the first instance.

parameters.name: fileExtensions
parameters.description: Specify the file extensions of the files to process.

patternDefinition.title: FileTabCharacter
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_FileTabCharacter
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks that there are no tab characters (`'\t'`) in the source code.

Rationale:

- Developers should not need to configure the tab width of their text
  editors in order to be able to read source code.
- From the Apache jakarta coding standards: In a distributed development
  environment, when the commit messages get sent to a mailing list, they
  are almost impossible to read if you use tabs.

parameters.name: fileExtensions
parameters.description: Specify the file extensions of the files to process.

parameters.name: ignorePattern
parameters.description: Specify pattern for lines to ignore.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: Specify the maximum line length allowed.

patternDefinition.title: LineLength
patternDefinition.description: Checkstyle_LineLength
patternDefinition.explanation:
Checks for long lines.

Rationale: Long lines are hard to read in printouts or if developers
have limited screen space for the source code, e.g. if the IDE displays
additional information like project tree, class hierarchy, etc.

patternDefinition.title: Short Array Syntax
patternDefinition.description: Short array syntax must be used to define arrays.

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-channel-no-empty-parameter - Channel path must not have empty parameter substitution pattern.
patternDefinition.description: Channel path must not have empty parameter substitution pattern.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-channel-no-empty-parameter

Channel parameter declarations cannot be empty, ex.`/given/{}` is invalid.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-channel-no-query-nor-fragment - Channel path must not include query ("?") or fragment ("#") delimiter.
patternDefinition.description: Channel path must not include query ("?") or fragment ("#") delimiter.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-channel-no-query-nor-fragment

Query parameters and fragments shouldn't be used in channel names. Instead, use bindings to define them.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-channel-no-trailing-slash - Channel path must not end with slash.
patternDefinition.description: Channel path must not end with slash.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-channel-no-trailing-slash

Keep trailing slashes off of channel names, as it can cause some confusion. Most messaging protocols will treat `example/foo` and `example/foo/` as different things. Keep in mind that tooling may replace slashes (`/`) with protocol-specific notation (e.g.: `.` for AMQP), therefore, a trailing slash may result in an invalid channel name in some protocols.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-channel-parameters - Channel parameters must be defined and there must be no redundant parameters.
patternDefinition.description: Channel parameters must be defined and there must be no redundant parameters.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-channel-parameters

All channel parameters should be defined in the `parameters` object of the channel. They should also not contain redundant parameters that do not exist in the channel address.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-channel-servers - Channel servers must be defined in the "servers" object.
patternDefinition.description: Channel servers must be defined in the "servers" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-channel-servers

Channel servers must be defined in the `servers` object.

**Bad Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Awesome API
  description: A very well-defined API
  version: "1.0"
servers:
  production:
    url: "stoplight.io"
    protocol: "https"
channels:
  hello:
    servers:
      - development
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Awesome API
  description: A very well-defined API
  version: "1.0"
servers:
  production:
    url: "stoplight.io"
    protocol: "https"
channels:
  hello:
    servers:
      - production
```

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-headers-schema-type-object - Headers schema type must be "object".
patternDefinition.description: Headers schema type must be "object".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-headers-schema-type-object

The schema definition of the application headers must be of type “object”.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-info-contact - Info object must have "contact" object.
patternDefinition.description: Info object must have "contact" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-info-contact

Info object should contain `contact` object.

Hopefully, your API description document is so good that nobody ever needs to contact you with questions, but that is rarely the case. The contact object has a few different options for contact details.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Awesome API
  version: "1.0"
  contact:
    name: A-Team
    email: a-team@goarmy.com
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-info-contact-properties - Contact object must have "name", "url" and "email".
patternDefinition.description: Contact object must have "name", "url" and "email".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-info-contact-properties

The [asyncapi-info-contact](#asyncapi-info-contact) rule will ask you to put in a contact object, and this rule will make sure it's full of the most useful properties: `name`, `url`, and `email`.

Putting in the name of the developer/team/department/company responsible for the API, along with the support email and help-desk/GitHub Issues/whatever URL means people know where to go for help. This can mean more money in the bank, instead of developers just wandering off or complaining online.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Awesome API
  description: A very well-defined API
  version: "1.0"
  contact:
    name: A-Team
    email: a-team@goarmy.com
    url: https://goarmy.com/apis/support
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-info-description - Info "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.description: Info "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-info-description

AsyncAPI object info `description` must be present and non-empty string.

Examples can contain Markdown so you can really go to town with them, implementing getting started information like where to find authentication keys, and how to use them.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  version: "1.0.0"
  title: Descriptive API
  description: >+
    Some description about the general point of this API, and why it exists when another similar but different API also exists.
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-info-license - Info object must have "license" object.
patternDefinition.description: Info object must have "license" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-info-license

The `info` object should have a `license` key.

It can be hard to pick a license, so if you don't have a lawyer around you can use [TLDRLegal](https://tldrlegal.com/) and [Choose a License](https://choosealicense.com/) to help give you an idea.

How useful this is in court is not entirely known, but having a license is better than not having a license.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  license:
    name: MIT
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-latest-version - Checking if the AsyncAPI document is using the latest version.
patternDefinition.description: Checking if the AsyncAPI document is using the latest version.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-latest-version

Checking if the AsyncAPI document is using the latest version.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-message-examples - Examples of message object should follow by "payload" and "headers" schemas.
patternDefinition.description: Examples of message object should follow by "payload" and "headers" schemas.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-message-examples

All `examples` in message object should follow `payload` and `headers` schemas.

**Bad Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Bad API
  version: "1.0.0"
components:
  messages:
    someMessage:
      payload:
        type: string
      headers:
        type: object
      examples:
        - payload: 2137
          headers: someHeader
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
asyncapi: "2.0.0"
info:
  title: Good API
  version: "1.0.0"
components:
  messages:
    someMessage:
      payload:
        type: string
      headers:
        type: object
      examples:
        - payload: foobar
          headers:
            someHeader: someValue
```

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-message-messageId-uniqueness - "messageId" must be unique across all the messages.
patternDefinition.description: "messageId" must be unique across all the messages.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-message-messageId-uniqueness

`messageId` must be unique across all the messages (except those one defined in the components).

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
channels:
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.on:
    publish:
      message:
        messageId: turnMessage
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.off:
    publish:
      message:
        messageId: turnMessage
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
channels:
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.on:
    publish:
      message:
        messageId: turnOnMessage
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.off:
    publish:
      message:
        messageId: turnOffMessage
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-operation-description - Operation "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.description: Operation "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-operation-description

Operation objects should have a description.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-operation-operationId - Operation must have "operationId".
patternDefinition.description: Operation must have "operationId".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-operation-operationId

This operation ID is essentially a reference for the operation. Tools may use it for defining function names, class method names, and even URL hashes in documentation systems.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-operation-operationId-uniqueness - "operationId" must be unique across all the operations.
patternDefinition.description: "operationId" must be unique across all the operations.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-operation-operationId-uniqueness

`operationId` must be unique across all the operations (except the ones defined in the components).

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
channels:
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.on:
    publish:
      operationId: turn
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.off:
    publish:
      operationId: turn
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
channels:
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.on:
    publish:
      operationId: turnOn
  smartylighting.streetlights.1.0.action.{streetlightId}.turn.off:
    publish:
      operationId: turnOff
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-operation-security - Operation have to reference a defined security schemes.
patternDefinition.description: Operation have to reference a defined security schemes.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-operation-security

Operation `security` values must match a scheme defined in the `components.securitySchemes` object. It also checks if there are `oauth2` scopes that have been defined for the given security.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
channels:
  "user/signup":
    publish:
      security:
        - petstore_auth: []
components:
  securitySchemes:
    petstore_auth: ...
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
channels:
  "user/signup":
    publish:
      security:
        - not_defined: []
components:
  securitySchemes:
    petstore_auth: ...
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-payload - Payloads must be valid against AsyncAPI Schema object.
patternDefinition.description: Payloads must be valid against AsyncAPI Schema object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-payload

When `schemaFormat` is undefined, the `payload` object should be valid against the AsyncAPI 2 Schema Object definition.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-payload-default - Default must be valid against its defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Default must be valid against its defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-payload-default

`default` objects should be valid against the `payload` they decorate.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
payload:
  type: object
  properties:
    value:
      type: integer
  required:
    - value
  default:
    value: 17
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
payload:
  type: object
  properties:
    value:
      type: integer
  required:
    - value
  default:
    value: nope!
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-payload-examples - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-payload-examples

Values of the `examples` array should be valid against the `payload` they decorate.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
payload:
  type: object
  properties:
    value:
      type: integer
  required:
    - value
  examples:
    - value: 13
    - value: 17
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
payload:
  type: object
  properties:
    value:
      type: integer
  required:
    - value
  examples:
    - value: nope! # Wrong type
    - notGoodEither: 17 # Missing required property
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-payload-unsupported-schemaFormat - Message schema validation is only supported with default unspecified "schemaFormat".
patternDefinition.description: Message schema validation is only supported with default unspecified "schemaFormat".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-payload-unsupported-schemaFormat

AsyncAPI can support various `schemaFormat` values. When unspecified, one of the following will be assumed:

application/vnd.aai.asyncapi;version=2.0.0
application/vnd.aai.asyncapi+json;version=2.0.0
application/vnd.aai.asyncapi+yaml;version=2.0.0

At this point, explicitly setting `schemaFormat` is not supported by Spectral, so if you use it this rule will emit an info message and skip validating the payload.

Other formats such as OpenAPI Schema Object, JSON Schema Draft 07, and Avro will be added in various upcoming versions.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-schema - Validate structure of AsyncAPI v2 specification.
patternDefinition.description: Validate structure of AsyncAPI v2 specification.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-schema

Validate structure of AsyncAPI v2 specification.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-schema-default - Default must be valid against its defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Default must be valid against its defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-schema-default

`default` objects should be valid against the `schema` they decorate.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-schema-examples - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-schema-examples

Values of the `examples` array should be valid against the `schema` they decorate.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-server-no-empty-variable - Server URL must not have empty variable substitution pattern.
patternDefinition.description: Server URL must not have empty variable substitution pattern.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-server-no-empty-variable

Server URL variable declarations cannot be empty, ex.`gigantic-server.com/{}` is invalid.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-server-no-trailing-slash - Server URL must not end with slash.
patternDefinition.description: Server URL must not end with slash.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-server-no-trailing-slash

Server URL should not have a trailing slash.

Some tooling forgets to strip trailing slashes off when it's joining the `servers.url` with `channels`, and you can get awkward URLs like `mqtt://example.com/broker//pets`. Best to just strip them off yourself.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: mqtt://example.com
  - url: mqtt://example.com/broker
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: mqtt://example.com/
  - url: mqtt://example.com/broker/
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-servers - AsyncAPI object must have non-empty "servers" object.
patternDefinition.description: AsyncAPI object must have non-empty "servers" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-servers

A non-empty `servers` object is expected to be located at the root of the document.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-server-security - Server have to reference a defined security schemes.
patternDefinition.description: Server have to reference a defined security schemes.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-server-security

Server `security` values must match a scheme defined in the `components.securitySchemes` object. It also checks if there are `oauth2` scopes that have been defined for the given security.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
servers:
  production:
    url: test.mosquitto.org
    security:
      - petstore_auth: []
components:
  securitySchemes:
    petstore_auth: ...
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
servers:
  production:
    url: test.mosquitto.org
    security:
      - not_defined: []
components:
  securitySchemes:
    petstore_auth: ...
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-server-variables - Server variables must be defined and there must be no redundant variables.
patternDefinition.description: Server variables must be defined and there must be no redundant variables.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-server-variables

All server URL variables should be defined in the `variables` object of the server. They should also not contain redundant variables that do not exist in the server address.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-tags - AsyncAPI object must have non-empty "tags" array.
patternDefinition.description: AsyncAPI object must have non-empty "tags" array.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-tags

AsyncAPI object should have non-empty `tags` array.

Why? Well, you _can_ reference tags arbitrarily in operations, and definition is optional...

```yaml
/invoices/{id}/items:
  get:
    tags:
      - Invoice Items
```

Defining tags allows you to add more information like a `description`. For more information see [asyncapi-tag-description](#asyncapi-tag-description).

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-tags-uniqueness - Each tag must have a unique name.
patternDefinition.description: Each tag must have a unique name.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-tags-uniqueness

Tags must not have duplicate names (identifiers).

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
tags:
  - name: "Badger"
  - name: "Badger"
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
tags:
  - name: "Aardvark"
  - name: "Badger"
```

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-unused-components-schema - Potentially unused components schema has been detected.
patternDefinition.description: Potentially unused components schema has been detected.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-unused-components-schema

Potential unused reusable `schema` entry has been detected.

<!-- theme: warning -->

_Warning:_ This rule may identify false positives when linting a specification
that acts as a library (a container storing reusable objects, leveraged by other
specifications that reference those objects).

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: asyncapi-unused-components-server - Potentially unused components server has been detected.
patternDefinition.description: Potentially unused components server has been detected.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# asyncapi-unused-components-server

Potential unused reusable `server` entry has been detected.

<!-- theme: warning -->

_Warning:_ This rule may identify false positives when linting a specification
that acts as a library (a container storing reusable objects, leveraged by other
specifications that reference those objects).

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: duplicated-entry-in-enum - Enum values must not have duplicate entry.
patternDefinition.description: Enum values must not have duplicate entry.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# duplicated-entry-in-enum

Each value of an `enum` must be different from one another.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
TheGoodModel:
  type: object
  properties:
    number_of_connectors:
      type: integer
      description: The number of extension points.
      enum:
        - 1
        - 2
        - 4
        - 8
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
TheBadModel:
  type: object
  properties:
    number_of_connectors:
      type: integer
      description: The number of extension points.
      enum:
        - 1
        - 2
        - 3
        - 2
```

patternDefinition.title: info-contact - Info object must have "contact" object.
patternDefinition.description: Info object must have "contact" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# info-contact

Info object should contain `contact` object.

Hopefully, your API description document is so good that nobody ever needs to contact you with questions, but that is rarely the case. The contact object has a few different options for contact details.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
openapi: "3.0.2"
info:
  title: Awesome API
  version: "1.0"
  contact:
    name: A-Team
    email: a-team@goarmy.com
```

patternDefinition.title: info-description - Info "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.description: Info "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# info-description

OpenAPI object info `description` must be present and non-empty string.

Examples can contain Markdown so you can really go to town with them, implementing getting started information like where to find authentication keys, and how to use them.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  version: "1.0.0"
  title: Descriptive API
  description: >+
    Some description about the general point of this API, and why it exists when another similar but different API also exists.

patternDefinition.title: no-eval-in-markdown - Markdown descriptions must not have "eval(".
patternDefinition.description: Markdown descriptions must not have "eval(".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# no-eval-in-markdown

This rule protects against an edge case, for anyone bringing in description documents from third parties and using the parsed content rendered in HTML/JS. If one of those third parties does something shady like injecting `eval()` JavaScript statements, it could lead to an XSS attack.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
openapi: "3.0.2"
info:
  title: 'some title with eval(',
```

patternDefinition.title: no-$ref-siblings - Property must not be placed among $ref
patternDefinition.description: Property must not be placed among $ref
patternDefinition.explanation:
# no-$ref-siblings

Before OpenAPI v3.1, keywords next to `$ref` were ignored by most tooling, but not all. This leads to inconsistent experiences depending on what combinations of tools are used. As of v3.1 $ref siblings are allowed, so this rule will not be applied.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
TheBadModel:
  $ref: "#/components/TheBadModelProperties"
  # This property should be ignored
  example: May or may not show up
```

patternDefinition.title: no-script-tags-in-markdown - Markdown descriptions must not have "<script>" tags.
patternDefinition.description: Markdown descriptions must not have "<script>" tags.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# no-script-tags-in-markdown

This rule protects against a potential hack, for anyone bringing in description documents from third parties and then generating HTML documentation. If one of those third parties does something shady like injecting `<script>` tags, they could easily execute arbitrary code on your domain, which if it's the same as your main application could be all sorts of terrible.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
openapi: "3.0.2"
info:
  title: 'some title with <script>alert("You are Hacked");</script>',
```

patternDefinition.title: oas2-anyOf - anyOf is not available in OpenAPI v2, it was added in OpenAPI v3
patternDefinition.description: anyOf is not available in OpenAPI v2, it was added in OpenAPI v3
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-anyOf

OpenAPI v3 keyword `anyOf` detected in OpenAPI v2 document.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-api-host - OpenAPI "host" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.description: OpenAPI "host" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-api-host

OpenAPI `host` must be present and non-empty string.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-api-schemes - OpenAPI host "schemes" must be present and non-empty array.
patternDefinition.description: OpenAPI host "schemes" must be present and non-empty array.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-api-schemes

OpenAPI host `schemes` must be present and non-empty array.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-discriminator - discriminator property must be defined and required
patternDefinition.description: discriminator property must be defined and required
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-discriminator

The discriminator property MUST be defined at this schema and it MUST be in the required property list.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-host-trailing-slash - Server URL must not have trailing slash.
patternDefinition.description: Server URL must not have trailing slash.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-host-trailing-slash

Server URL should not have a trailing slash.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-oneOf - oneOf is not available in OpenAPI v2, it was added in OpenAPI v3
patternDefinition.description: oneOf is not available in OpenAPI v2, it was added in OpenAPI v3
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-oneOf

OpenAPI v3 keyword `oneOf` detected in OpenAPI v2 document.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-operation-formData-consume-check - Operations with "in: formData" parameter must include "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" or "multipart/form-data" in their "consumes" property.
patternDefinition.description: Operations with "in: formData" parameter must include "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" or "multipart/form-data" in their "consumes" property.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-operation-formData-consume-check

Operations with an `in: formData` parameter must include `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` or `multipart/form-data` in their `consumes` property.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-operation-security-defined - Operation "security" values must match a scheme defined in the "securityDefinitions" object.
patternDefinition.description: Operation "security" values must match a scheme defined in the "securityDefinitions" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-operation-security-defined

Operation `security` values must match a scheme defined in the `securityDefinitions` object.
Ignores empty `security` values for cases where authentication is explicitly not required or optional.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-schema - Validate structure of OpenAPI v2 specification.
patternDefinition.description: Validate structure of OpenAPI v2 specification.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-schema

Validate structure of OpenAPI v2 specification.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas2-unused-definition - Potentially unused definition has been detected.
patternDefinition.description: Potentially unused definition has been detected.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-unused-definition

Potential unused reusable `definition` entry has been detected.

<!-- theme: warning -->

patternDefinition.title: oas2-valid-media-example - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas2-valid-media-example

Examples must be valid against their defined schema. Common reasons you may see errors are:

- The value used for property examples is not the same type indicated in the schema (`string` vs. `integer`, for example).
- Examples contain properties not included in the schema.

**Recommended:** Yes

For example, if you have a Pet object with an `id` property as type `integer`, and `name` and `petType` properties as type `string`, the `examples` properties type should match the schema:

```yaml
schemas:
  Pet:
    title: Pet
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        type: integer
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - id
      - name
      - petType
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
paths:
  '/pet/{petId}':
    get:
      ...
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Pet Found
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pet'
          examples:
            Get Pet Bubbles:
              id: 123
              name: 'Bubbles'
              petType: 'dog'
```

**Bad Example**

This would throw an error since `petType` is an `integer`, not a `string`.

```yaml
paths:
  '/pet/{petId}':
    get:
      ...
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Pet Found
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pet'
          examples:
            Get Pet Bubbles:
              id: 123
              name: 'Bubbles'
              petType: 123
```

patternDefinition.title: oas2-valid-schema-example - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
At Codacy we strive to provide great descriptions for our patterns.
With good explanations developers can better understand issues and even learn how to fix them.

For this tool we are not yet meeting this standard but you can help us improve the docs.
To know more, take a look at our [tool documentation guide](https://docs.codacy.com/related-tools/tool-developer-guide/#documentation).

You can also visit the tool's website to find useful tips about the patterns.

patternDefinition.title: oas3-api-servers - OpenAPI "servers" must be present and non-empty array.
patternDefinition.description: OpenAPI "servers" must be present and non-empty array.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-api-servers

OpenAPI `servers` must be present and non-empty array.

**Recommended:** Yes

Share links to any servers that people might care about. If this is going to be given to internal people then usually that is localhost (so they know the right port number), staging, and production.

```yaml
servers:
  - url: https://example.com/api
    description: Production server
  - url: https://staging.example.com/api
    description: Staging server
  - url: http://localhost:3001
    description: Development server
```

If this is going out to the world, maybe have production and a general sandbox people can play with.

patternDefinition.title: oas3-examples-value-or-externalValue - Examples must have either "value" or "externalValue" field.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must have either "value" or "externalValue" field.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-examples-value-or-externalValue

Examples for `requestBody` or response examples can have an `externalValue` or a `value`, but they cannot have both.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
paths:
  /pet:
    put:
      operationId: "replace-pet"
      requestBody:
        content:
          "application/json":
            examples:
              foo:
                summary: A foo example
                value: { "foo": "bar" }
                externalValue: "http://example.org/foo.json"
                # marp! no, can only have one or the other
```

patternDefinition.title: oas3-operation-security-defined - Operation "security" values must match a scheme defined in the "components.securitySchemes" object.
patternDefinition.description: Operation "security" values must match a scheme defined in the "components.securitySchemes" object.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-operation-security-defined

Operation `security` values must match a scheme defined in the `components.securitySchemes` object.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas3-schema - Validate structure of OpenAPI v3 specification.
patternDefinition.description: Validate structure of OpenAPI v3 specification.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-schema

Validate structure of OpenAPI v3 specification.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: oas3-server-trailing-slash - Server URL must not have trailing slash.
patternDefinition.description: Server URL must not have trailing slash.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-server-trailing-slash

Server URL should not have a trailing slash.

Some tooling forgets to strip trailing slashes off when it's joining the `servers.url` with `paths`, and you can get awkward URLs like `https://example.com/api//pets`. Best to just strip them off yourself.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: https://example.com
  - url: https://example.com/api
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: https://example.com/
  - url: https://example.com/api/
```

patternDefinition.title: oas3-server-variables - Server variables must be defined and valid and there must be no unused variables.
patternDefinition.description: Server variables must be defined and valid and there must be no unused variables.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-server-variables

This rule ensures that server variables defined in OpenAPI Specification 3 (OAS3) and 3.1 are valid, not unused, and result in a valid URL. Properly defining and using server variables is crucial for the accurate representation of API endpoints and preventing potential misconfigurations or security issues.

**Recommended**: Yes

**Bad Examples**

1. **Missing definition for a URL variable**:

```yaml
servers:
  - url: "https://api.{region}.example.com/v1"
    variables:
      version:
        default: "v1"
```

In this example, the variable **`{region}`** in the URL is not defined within the **`variables`** object.

2. **Unused URL variable:**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: "https://api.example.com/v1"
    variables:
      region:
        default: "us-west"
```

Here, the variable **`region`** is defined but not used in the server URL.

3. **Invalid default value for an allowed value variable**:

```yaml
servers:
  - url: "https://api.{region}.example.com/v1"
    variables:
      region:
        default: "us-south"
        enum:
          - "us-west"
          - "us-east"
```

The default value 'us-south' isn't one of the allowed values in the **`enum`**.

4. **Invalid resultant URL**:

```yaml
servers:
  - url: "https://api.example.com:{port}/v1"
    variables:
      port:
        default: "8o80"
```

Substituting the default value of **`{port}`** results in an invalid URL.

**Good Example**

```yaml
servers:
  - url: "https://api.{region}.example.com/{version}"
    variables:
      region:
        default: "us-west"
        enum:
          - "us-west"
          - "us-east"
      version:
        default: "v1"
```

In this example, both **`{region}`** and **`{version}`** variables are properly defined and used in the server URL. Also, the default value for **`region`** is within the allowed values.

patternDefinition.title: oas3-unused-component - N/A
patternDefinition.description: N/A

patternDefinition.title: oas3-valid-media-example - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-valid-media-example

Examples must be valid against their defined schema. This rule is applied to Media Type objects.

**Recommended:** Yes

For example, if you have a Pet object with an `id` property as type `integer`, and `name` and `petType` properties as type `string`, the examples properties type should match the schema:

```yaml
schemas:
  Pet:
    title: Pet
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        type: integer
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - id
      - name
      - petType
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
paths:
  '/pet/{petId}':
    get:
      ...
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Pet Found
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pet'
          examples:
            Get Pet Bubbles:
              id: 123
              name: 'Bubbles'
              petType: 'dog'
```

**Bad Example**

This would throw an error since `petType` is an `integer`, not a `string`.

```yaml
paths:
  '/pet/{petId}':
    get:
      ...
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Pet Found
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pet'
          examples:
            Get Pet Bubbles:
              id: 123
              name: 'Bubbles'
              petType: 123
```

patternDefinition.title: oas3-valid-schema-example - Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.description: Examples must be valid against their defined schema.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# oas3-valid-schema-example

Examples must be valid against their defined schema. This rule is applied to Schema objects.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
schemas:
  Pet:
    title: Pet
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        type: integer
        example: 123
      name:
        type: string
        example: Bubbles
      petType:
        type: string
        example: dog
    required:
      - id
      - name
      - petType
```

**Bad Example**

This would throw an error since the example value for `petType` is an `integer`, not a `string`.

```yaml
schemas:
  Pet:
    title: Pet
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        type: integer
        example: 123
      name:
        type: string
        example: Bubbles
      petType:
        type: string
        example: 123
    required:
      - name
      - petType
```

patternDefinition.title: openapi-tags-uniqueness - Each tag must have a unique name.
patternDefinition.description: Each tag must have a unique name.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# openapi-tags-uniqueness

OpenAPI object must not have duplicated tag names (identifiers).

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
tags:
  - name: "Badger"
  - name: "Badger"
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
tags:
  - name: "Aardvark"
  - name: "Badger"
```

**Recommended:** No

patternDefinition.title: operation-description - Operation "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.description: Operation "description" must be present and non-empty string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-description

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: operation-operationId - Operation must have "operationId".
patternDefinition.description: Operation must have "operationId".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-operationId

This operation ID is essentially a reference for the operation, which can be used to visually suggest a connection to other operations. This is like some theoretical static HATEOAS-style referencing, but it's also used for the URL in some documentation systems.

Make the value `lower-hyphen-case`, and try and think of a name for the action which does not relate to the HTTP message. Base it off the actual action being performed. `create-polygon`? `search-by-polygon`? `filter-companies`?

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: operation-operationId-unique - Every operation must have unique "operationId".
patternDefinition.description: Every operation must have unique "operationId".
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-operationId-unique

Every operation must have a unique `operationId`.

Why? A lot of documentation systems use this as an identifier, some SDK generators convert them to a method name, among other things.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
paths:
  /pet:
    patch:
      operationId: "update-pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: ok
    put:
      operationId: "update-pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: ok
```

**Good Example**

```yaml
paths:
  /pet:
    patch:
      operationId: "update-pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: ok
    put:
      operationId: "replace-pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: ok
```

patternDefinition.title: operation-operationId-valid-in-url - N/A
patternDefinition.description: N/A
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-operationId-valid-in-url

Seeing as operationId is often used for unique URLs in documentation systems, it's a good idea to avoid non-URL-safe characters.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
paths:
  /pets:
    get:
      operationId: get cats
```

patternDefinition.title: operation-parameters - Operation parameters are unique and non-repeating.
patternDefinition.description: Operation parameters are unique and non-repeating.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-parameters

Operation parameters are unique and non-repeating.

1. Operations must have unique `name` + `in` parameters.
2. Operation cannot have both `in: body` and `in: formData` parameters. (OpenAPI v2.0)
3. Operation must have only one `in: body` parameter. (OpenAPI v2.0)

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: operation-success-response - Operation must have at least one "2xx" or "3xx" response.
patternDefinition.description: Operation must have at least one "2xx" or "3xx" response.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-success-response

Operation must have at least one `2xx` or `3xx` response. Any API operation (endpoint) can fail, but presumably, it is also meant to do something constructive at some point. If you forget to write out a success case for this API, then this rule will let you know.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Bad Example**

```yaml
paths:
  /path:
    get:
      responses:
        418:
          description: teapot
```

patternDefinition.title: operation-tag-defined - Operation tags must be defined in global tags.
patternDefinition.description: Operation tags must be defined in global tags.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-tag-defined

Operation tags should be defined in global tags.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: operation-tags - Operation must have non-empty "tags" array.
patternDefinition.description: Operation must have non-empty "tags" array.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# operation-tags

Operation should have non-empty `tags` array.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: path-declarations-must-exist - N/A
patternDefinition.description: N/A
patternDefinition.explanation:
# path-declarations-must-exist

Path parameter declarations cannot be empty, ex.`/given/{}` is invalid.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: path-keys-no-trailing-slash - N/A
patternDefinition.description: N/A
patternDefinition.explanation:
# path-keys-no-trailing-slash

Keep trailing slashes off of paths, as it can cause some confusion. Some web tooling (like mock servers, real servers, code generators, application frameworks, etc.) will treat `example.com/foo` and `example.com/foo/` as the same thing, but other tooling will not. Avoid any confusion by just documenting them without the slash, and maybe some tooling will let people shove a / on there when they're using it, or maybe not, but at least the docs are suggesting how it should be done properly.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: path-not-include-query - Path must not include query string.
patternDefinition.description: Path must not include query string.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# path-not-include-query

Don't put query string items in the path, they belong in parameters with `in: query`.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: path-params - Path parameters must be defined and valid.
patternDefinition.description: Path parameters must be defined and valid.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# path-params

Path parameters are correct and valid.

1. For every parameter referenced in the path string (i.e: `/users/{userId}`), the parameter must be defined in either
   `path.parameters`, or `operation.parameters` objects (non-standard HTTP operations will be silently ignored.)

2. every `path.parameters` and `operation.parameters` parameter must be used in the path string.

**Recommended:** Yes

patternDefinition.title: typed-enum - Enum values must respect the specified type.
patternDefinition.description: Enum values must respect the specified type.
patternDefinition.explanation:
# typed-enum

Enum values should respect the `type` specifier.

**Recommended:** Yes

**Good Example**

```yaml
TheGoodModel:
  type: object
  properties:
    number_of_connectors:
      type: integer
      description: The number of extension points.
      enum:
        - 1
        - 2
        - 4
        - 8
```

**Bad Example**

```yaml
TheBadModel:
  type: object
  properties:
    number_of_connectors:
      type: integer
      description: The number of extension points.
      enum:
        - 1
        - 2
        - "a string!"
        - 8
```
